question_text: How do you diagnose and resolve display issues that aren't related to complete video failure?
answer_options: Display issues only occur due to software problems and require reinstalling applications
Check resolution settings, refresh rates, color depth, cable quality, monitor compatibility
Display problems are always caused by network connectivity issues
All display issues require immediate replacement of the graphics card
correct_answer: Check resolution settings, refresh rates, color depth, cable quality, monitor compatibility
explanation: Display issues (distortion, wrong colors, flickering) require systematic checking: 1) Verify resolution and refresh rate settings, 2) Test different color depths, 3) Check cable quality and connections, 4) Test monitor with different source, 5) Update graphics drivers, 6) Check for electromagnetic interference, 7) Verify monitor specifications match output capabilities.

question_text: What are common monitor problems and how do you distinguish them from graphics card issues?
answer_options: Monitor problems only affect brightness and have no other symptoms
Dead pixels, backlight failure, power issues - test with different source to isolate from graphics card
All monitor problems automatically indicate graphics card failure
Monitor problems only occur during specific software applications
correct_answer: Dead pixels, backlight failure, power issues - test with different source to isolate from graphics card
explanation: Monitor problems include: dead pixels, backlight failure, power issues, button malfunctions, and physical damage. Distinguish from graphics card issues by: testing monitor with different source (laptop, phone), checking for problems across all inputs, verifying power LED status, and testing known good monitor with suspect system.

question_text: What constitutes screen failure and what are the different types you might encounter?
answer_options: Screen failure only refers to complete darkness with no other variations
Complete display loss, partial display, distortion, color problems - hardware or connection related
Screen failure exclusively indicates software corruption issues
All screen failures require operating system reinstallation
correct_answer: Complete display loss, partial display, distortion, color problems - hardware or connection related
explanation: Screen failure types: 1) Complete loss (no signal), 2) Partial display (missing sections), 3) Distortion (wavy lines, geometric problems), 4) Color problems (wrong colors, missing color channels), 5) Flickering or intermittent display. Can be caused by cable problems, graphics card failure, monitor defects, or power supply issues.

question_text: What display hardware components should you check during video troubleshooting?
answer_options: Only the monitor screen itself without considering other components
Graphics card, monitor, cables, power supplies, motherboard video outputs, adapters
Display hardware problems are always software-related issues
Only internal components without considering external display connections
correct_answer: Graphics card, monitor, cables, power supplies, motherboard video outputs, adapters
explanation: Display hardware includes: graphics card (dedicated or integrated), monitor, video cables (VGA, DVI, HDMI, DisplayPort), power supplies (for both PC and monitor), motherboard video outputs, port adapters, and cable converters. Systematic testing of each component helps isolate hardware failures from software issues.

question_text: What is video output troubleshooting and what are the key things to verify?
answer_options: Only checking software video player applications and codecs
Verify signal generation from PC, cable integrity, monitor input selection, compatibility
Video output problems are exclusively network streaming issues
Only testing with high-resolution displays and gaming applications
correct_answer: Verify signal generation from PC, cable integrity, monitor input selection, compatibility
explanation: Video output troubleshooting verifies: 1) PC generates video signal (test with known good monitor), 2) Cable carries signal properly (test with different cable), 3) Monitor receives and displays signal (check input selection), 4) Resolution/refresh rate compatibility, 5) Proper video output selection (integrated vs dedicated graphics).

question_text: What is the process of elimination in motherboard troubleshooting and how do you implement it effectively?
answer_options: Random removal of components without systematic approach
Systematically remove non-essential components to isolate problems - start with minimal configuration
Process of elimination only applies to software troubleshooting procedures
Immediately replace all components without testing individual parts
correct_answer: Systematically remove non-essential components to isolate problems - start with minimal configuration
explanation: Process of elimination for motherboards: 1) Start with minimal configuration (CPU, 1 RAM stick, power), 2) Test basic functionality, 3) Add components one at a time, 4) Test after each addition, 5) When problem appears, last added component is suspect, 6) Remove and retest to confirm. This isolates defective components and prevents damage from faulty parts.

question_text: What should you consider regarding motherboard warranty during troubleshooting and repairs?
answer_options: Warranty considerations are irrelevant during troubleshooting procedures
Check warranty status before disassembly, document problems, follow RMA procedures if covered
All motherboards have lifetime warranties that cover any type of damage
Warranty only covers software issues and never hardware problems
correct_answer: Check warranty status before disassembly, document problems, follow RMA procedures if covered
explanation: Motherboard warranty considerations: 1) Check warranty status and terms before opening case, 2) Document problems and symptoms, 3) Take photos of damage if visible, 4) Follow manufacturer's RMA procedures, 5) Avoid actions that void warranty (removing warranty stickers, physical damage from troubleshooting), 6) Keep purchase receipts and original packaging.

question_text: How do driver issues contribute to motherboard troubleshooting and what is the resolution approach?
answer_options: Driver issues only affect external peripherals and never motherboard functions
Chipset, BIOS, and component drivers affect stability - update systematically from manufacturer
All driver problems require complete operating system reinstallation
Driver issues are always caused by hardware failure and require replacement
correct_answer: Chipset, BIOS, and component drivers affect stability - update systematically from manufacturer
explanation: Driver issues affecting motherboards: chipset drivers, BIOS updates, USB controller drivers, audio drivers, and network drivers. Resolution: 1) Identify motherboard model, 2) Download latest drivers from manufacturer website, 3) Update chipset drivers first, 4) Update BIOS if needed, 5) Update individual component drivers, 6) Test stability after each update.

question_text: What are software conflicts in motherboard troubleshooting and how do they manifest?
answer_options: Software conflicts only occur between user applications and don't affect hardware
Driver conflicts, service conflicts, hardware resource conflicts causing instability and crashes
All software conflicts indicate physical hardware damage to motherboard
Software conflicts exclusively affect network connectivity and nothing else
correct_answer: Driver conflicts, service conflicts, hardware resource conflicts causing instability and crashes
explanation: Software conflicts affecting motherboards: driver conflicts between different hardware manufacturers, service conflicts from multiple hardware management utilities, resource conflicts (IRQ, DMA, I/O addresses), and compatibility issues between BIOS settings and OS. Symptoms: random crashes, BSOD, device failures, and system instability. Resolution requires systematic driver management and conflict resolution.

question_text: What is power switch verification in motherboard troubleshooting and why is it important?
answer_options: Testing electrical outlets and power cords for proper voltage delivery
Verify case power button connects properly to motherboard and functions correctly
Power switch verification only applies to laptop computers with battery systems
Checking power supply unit efficiency ratings and certification standards
correct_answer: Verify case power button connects properly to motherboard and functions correctly
explanation: Power switch verification tests: 1) Check front panel connector attachment to motherboard, 2) Verify correct pin placement for power button, 3) Test by manually shorting power pins on motherboard, 4) Check for stuck or damaged case power button, 5) Verify power LED connections. Important because faulty power switches can prevent system startup entirely.
